newsitem.title: UK: European oil traders see Iraqi exports in January.
newsitem.headline: European oil traders see Iraqi exports in January.

text.p: Most European crude oil traders expect Iraqi oil exports to start flowing in January and doubt if any cargoes will leave Turkey's Ceyhan terminal in December, they said on Monday.

Neither of the favourites to lift the first barrels, Elf and Total, by Monday had signed a contract with Iraq's State Oil Marketing Organisation (SOMO), spokesmen for the companies said on Monday. And Turkey's state oil company Tupras declined to say whether it had or not.

United Nations' Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali gave the final go-ahead on Monday, which could technically lead to the first sale occuring on Thursday, after the contract has been inspected by the U.N.'s special contract overseers.
But dealers said it would take several weeks to organise shipping and prepare refineries to accept the crude once a deal is struck.
"SOMO believed exports would start as soon as the meters were inspected, but in the real world it will take buyers a few weeks to sort out shipping," said a trader at a major European oil company.

"Contracts have to be reviewed, contracts have to be signed, ships need to be chartered. The first exports are at least 7-10 days away, but I tend to think you won't really see the oil until January."
Another said: "I would not be surprised to see a cargo before the year-end, but the majority will be into January."
